quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Collections[/h1]

The .NET Framework provides a number of[b] generic collection classes[/b], useful for storing and manipulating data.
These classes are contained in the [b]System.Collections.Generic[/b] namespace.
[b]List [/b]is one of the commonly used collection classes: [code format="cs" codeId="918"][b]List<string> colors = new List<string>();[/b]
colors.Add("Red");
colors.Add("Green");
colors.Add("Pink");
colors.Add("Blue");

foreach (var color in colors) {
  Console.WriteLine(color);
}
/*Outputs
Red
Green
Pink
Blue
*/[/code]
We defined a List that stores strings and iterated through it using a [b]foreach [/b]loop. 
The List class contains a number of useful methods:
[b]Add [/b]adds an element to the List.
[b]Clear [/b]removes all elements from the List.
[b]Contains [/b]determines whether the specified element is contained in the List.
[b]Count [/b]returns the number of elements in the List.
[b]Insert [/b]adds an element at the specified index.
[b]Reverse [/b]reverses the order of the elements in the List.
[note]So why use Lists instead of arrays?
Because, unlike arrays, the group of objects you work with in a collection can grow and shrink dynamically.[/note]

quizzes.question: Which of the following collections is based on the FIFO method?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Collections[/h1]

Commonly used generic collection types include:
[b]Dictionary<TKey, TValue>[/b] represents a collection of key/value pairs that are organized based on the key.
[b]List<T>[/b] represents a list of objects that can be accessed by index. Provides methods to search, sort, and modify lists.
[b]Queue<T>[/b] represents a first in, first out (FIFO) collection of objects.
[b]Stack<T>[/b] represents a last in, first out (LIFO) collection of objects.
[note]Choose the type of collection class based on the data you need to store and the operations you need.[/note]
